EEM203.name: Data Analysis for the Agri-Food System
EEM203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
EEM203.description: Introduction to data analysis tools used in the management of food systems.
EEM203.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Agribusiness Management Major or in the Agribusiness Management Minor or in the Environmental Economics Minor or in the Environmental Economics and Management major or in the Food Industry Management Major or in the Food Industry Management Minor.

EEM255.name: Ecological Economics
EEM255.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
EEM255.description: Relationship between the economy and the natural environment. Economic organization and sustainability. Economic concepts applied to natural resources and agriculture.

EEM260.name: World Food, Population and Poverty
EEM260.description: Description and analysis of world food, population and poverty problems. Interrelationships between developed and developing countries.

EEM303.name: Economics of Decision Making in the Agri-Food System
EEM303.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
EEM303.description: Managerial economics with applications focusing on agriculture, food, and resources issues.
EEM303.prerequisite: (MTH 124 and EC 201 and EC 202 and ABM 203) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 315)

EEM320.name: Environmental Economics
EEM320.description: Analytical methods for evaluating economic impacts of environmental policies and understanding the economic causes of environmental problems.
EEM320.prerequisite: (EEM 255 and EC 201) and (ABM 203 or approval of department)

EEM335.name: Taxes, Government Spending and Public Policy
EEM335.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EEM335.description: Economics of the public sector. Public goods, externalities, design and incidence of the tax system. Equity and efficiency effects of government programs.

EEM404.name: Public Sector Budgeting and Program Evaluation
EEM404.description: Structure and finance of government. Approaches to public sector budgeting. Evaluation of output of programs and community services. Impact and multiple outcome analysis.
EEM404.prerequisite: (EC 201 or EEM 255) and EC 202 and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
EEM404.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

EEM405.name: Corporate Environmental Management (W)
EEM405.description: Integration of environmental protection and pollution prevention with business management. Economic and strategic analysis of environmental protection.
EEM405.prerequisite: (EEM 255) and (ACC 201 or ACC 230 or ABM 130) and ABM 203 and (((ABM 303 or EC 301) or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

EEM460.name: Natural Resource Economics
EEM460.description: Economic framework for analyzing natural resource management decisions. Spatial and inter-temporal allocation of renewable and nonrenewable resources. Special emphasis on institutions, externalities, and public interests in resource management.

EEM464.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Policy in Michigan
EEM464.description: State legislative process and its role in environmental and natural resource policy formulation. Influence of lobbying, citizen engagement and political factors.
EEM464.prerequisite: CSUS 200 or EEM 255 or approval of department

EEM465.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Law
EEM465.description: Legal principles and process related to the environment and natural resources. Common law, constitutional law, statutory and administrative law.
EEM465.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

EEM490.name: Independent and Supervised Study
EEM490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EEM490.description: In-depth independent study of topics affecting public resource management. Complementary with previous coursework, adapted to career aspirations.
EEM490.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Environmental Economics and Management major. Approval of department; application required.

EEM493.name: Professional Internship in Environmental Economics and Management
EEM493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EEM493.description: Supervised professional experience in agencies, organizations, or businesses related to environmental economics and policy.
EEM493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Environmental Economics and Management major. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses
